citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Department of Interior and the National Geophysical Data Center, NOAA
citeinfo.title: Airborne geophysical survey: Mt. Adams, Washington

descript.abstract: Aeromagnetic data were collected along flight lines by instruments in an aircraft that recorded magnetic-field values and locations. This dataset presents latitude, longitude, altitude, and magnetic-field values.
descript.purpose: Aeromagnetic surveys are used for geophysical prospecting. Some variations in magnetic measurements are caused by rocks that contain significant amounts of magnetic minerals (magnetite being the most common). These anomalies reflect variations in the amount and type of magnetic material and the shape and depth of the body of rock. The features and patterns of aeromagnetic anomalies can also be used to delineate details of subsurface geology including the locations of buried faults and the thickness of surficial sedimentary rocks.

idinfo.useconst: none. Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey and the National Geophysical Data Center would be appreciated in products derived from these data.

browse.browsed: Reduced-size image depicting the data, 642 x 683 pixels, 171,494 bytes

idinfo.datacred: These USGS employees contributed to reformatting and archiving these data: Bob Kucks, Pat Hill
idinfo.native: These data were originally recorded on CD_ROM's.

attracc.attraccr: The data in this file have been processed using various formulas and methods that are not usually documented but that represent industry standard practices for airborne data reduction. See operations report for discussion on data acquisition and processing.

dataqual.logic: The data in this file were collected by a single contractor or group who were responsible for collecting and processing the data. The data from this survey were collected using the same instruments (magnetometers, altimeters, navigational systems) throughout the survey and were collected in a normal length of time with no long delays between survey beginning and end. Survey contracts specified the conditions and specifications under which these data were collected. Standard industry practices of the time were followed in data collection and processing.
dataqual.complete: Loss of data due to poor transmission, channel dropout, obvious spiking, missing channels, and other obvious errors may have been replaced with the value -9999.9.

horizpa.horizpar: Horizontal positions of the survey aircraft used to collect data were determined using GPS satellite navigation.

vertacc.vertaccr: The aircraft vertical position was determined using the navigational positioning equipment on the aircraft, which were radar altimeter and barometric altimeter. Radar altimeters are estimated to have an error of 2-5% of the altitude (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication). Barometric altimeters are quite accurate, but are typically operated in an uncorrected mode. The diurnal variation in air pressure over the course of a flight can produce a 50-100 ft error in the barometric altimeter reading. In addition, pressure microcells create short- period air pressure changes equivalent to about 10 ft. under typical conditions (Richard Hansen, PRJ, Inc., written communication) This data set was collected as a draped survey having an average terrain clearance of 200 ft. Because aircraft cannot safely maintain a constant terrain clearance, error in vertical position is introduced.

procstep.procdesc: Conversion of measured values to geographic position and magnetic values was performed by the contractor using industry standard practices.

USGS personnel used the software package Oasis Montaj by Geosoft, Inc., to read in the original contractor's data. Few, if any, corrections were made to the original data. Minor changes may have been made to the original format. A readme.txt file was created to outline the format of the .xyz file.

overview.eaover: Airborne survey specifications These items are constant for the entire survey Project number: 4272 Project name: Mt. Adams, Washington Survey flown by: Fugro Survey flown for: U.S. Geological Survey Approx. no. of line miles: 62 Survey height: 200 ft Altitude method: Draped over terrain Flight-line spacing: 0.155 mi Flight-line direction: E-W Aircraft used: SA315B Lama helicopter Airport - arrival: unknown Airport - departure: unknown Tow cable length: 100 feet Magnetometer used: Geometrics 822 cesium vapor Data recording interval: 0.1 second Regional field removed: IGRF
overview.eadetcit: Nettleton, L.L., 1971, Elementary Gravity and Magnetics for Geologists and Seismologists: Society of Exploration Geophysicists Monograph Series No. 1. Dobrin, M.B., 1976, Introduction to Geophysical Prospecting: New York, McGraw-Hill Book Company, Sheriff, R.E., 1984, Encyclopedic dictionary of exploration geophysics: Tulsa, OK, Society of Exploration Geophysicists.
